content:
I don't know much about Latin Squares, so I went online.

The description doesn't say what makes two Latin Square distinct from each other.  I notice that most resources seem to consider the following two squares...

| 123 | 321 | 
| 231 | 213 | 
| 312 | 132 | 

... to be the EXACT same Latin Square.  (The symbols 1 and 3 are exchanged in the right hand square, but the square is the same)

This is because, in Latin Squares, the symbols being used are usually not considered important, only the patterns!  We could swap 1 for 'Elephant', 2 for 'Green' and 3 for 'Smiley Face' - and it'd still be the same Latin Square.

And that's where my confusion comes from :

Number of 'Latin Squares' != Number of representations.

So, I found it the puzzle vague in what was being asked for :

1. Count the unique Latin Squares squares (irrespective of their symbols) as most articles on Latin Squares seem to consider appropriate.

or;

2. Count the number of possible symbolic representations, even where they would actually represent the SAME Latin Square (*)

If you already understand Latin Squares, and are therefore pattern-focused, it seems like the description asks Question 1 ... and if you're new to Latin Squares, or are symbol-focused, it seems like it asks Question 2.

The given example doesn't clarify, as the answer is 1 in both cases.

Or, am I just being an idiot?
Added a more difficult test case

The 9x9 VALIDATOR seems too easy. My python "brute force" (recurse by-row, by-column, sum by looping through 1..N: if i is not present in the row or column, call recursively) was too slow for test case 9x9 but passed the validator.

For a medium difficulty puzzle I figured I'd need to optimize something?

Some numbers for the python brute force:
- 9x9 validator takes 3.4 sec on CG (i guess python has a big time limit?) and 2.9 sec on my laptop
- 9x9 test case takes 32 sec on my laptop. (can't run it on CG)

Taking some of the digits out of the validator, I get something that runs in 27 sec on my laptop:

9
087604321
800000002
700000003
600523000
000372005
401230006
300000007
200000008
103050780

29312

This test case shows "Solved in 89366 us" in the C++ solution.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: I've always been a fan of latin squares problems and this one was really interesting

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle, interesting to resolve. 
In javascript I had to optimize a little my search algorithm for the last challenges (9x9). That make the puzzle more interesting to be made.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting puzzle, and there aren't many similar puzzles on CodinGame where one is required to work out not just one, but all solutions and count them.

Interesting puzzle :)

I've solved it using DLX in python in about an hour, and the solution is slightly fewer than 100 lines (including 20 to 30 lines of comments and blank lines).

In the first sentence in the Goal section, I suggest to use "Count" instead of "Find" to be more precise.

No other comments from me. I'll review it again another day to make sure I haven't missed anything before approving it.

Thanks for your comments. I am interested in your timings in Python. I have designed the puzzles so that they take around 10ms to solve with C++ unoptimized but I would like to push further the envelope if possible. My goal is that people trying to solve it use optimized implementations not just brute force stuff.

The tricky part in this puzzle is that, although it is very compute intensive, it should be doable with slow languages. Imagine that the timings I have are with unoptimized C++. Performance-wise, this represents several orders of magnitude with Python. PHP, Ruby and al. are probably even worse.
So I had to nerf my test cases.
Regarding your specific problem, I think it's really related to your algorithm. With mine, more solutions to find result in longer timings. 
That said, I really want people to use smart algorithms: your test case seems compatible with an optimized Python implementation and the time frame allocated  to that language.
Great, now I feel motivated to try to beat the harder validator! I'd never heard of DLX so I'm going to noodle about this for a while, and then peek at an explainer of the algorithm.

I've timed my code just now. Unsurprisingly, the more the solutions, the longer my code takes. For all those cases where the number of solutions is fewer than 10000, less than 1 second is needed; for those with more than 10000 solutions, 1.2 to 1.9 seconds is needed.
Thanks. Unless Dancing Links with ZDD can improve speed, providing more compute intensive tests would time out for many languages. I'll keep them as they are.
Minor point: both "n Ã— n" and "n x n" are used. Maybe change one of them for consistency?
You really have a hawk eye ! Done
I hope I do have hawk eyes! I didn't spot this before: "a n x n" vs "an n x n" ðŸ˜… Sorry for that.
